text:
I find the quality and maturity of Pluto to be very low, and I’m annoyed. However I do need to use it because of Computational Thinking. Here are two examples:

Several times in the last weeks I’ve had the UI loose connection with the kernel somehow. I may be able to write something on the UI, but nothing gets executed. When I kill Pluto on the REPL and re-start things, I see that latest things I wrote on the notebook are not saved.

Second is about the with_terminal(). I tried figuring out why my function is not working properly so I went to the trouble of copy-pasting the code that calls it to another cell, edited the cell so it properly calls that. Then I invoke the cell, verify that I can get some output, but because the internal code throws a MethodError, it no longer displays the output when I really need it. Ok, I try to look for the output in the actual terminal, but because the code is called by several cells in the notebook, I have way too much output. Then I edit the function name so the other cells don’t call it.

None of this would have been a problem with a Jupyter notebook.

text: If you were just going to dunk on Pluto, could you use the <#C67TK21LJ|gripes> channel for that next time so this channel doesn't get cluttered unnecessarily?

elements.text: If you were just going to dunk on Pluto, could you use the
channel for that next time so this channel doesn't get cluttered unnecessarily?

text:
Moreover, you're comparing a mostly one-man project that's little over 1 year old and nowhere near version 1.0 with a 6-year-old team project with large corporate support! Of course things are going to fail!  Of course it's not mature! It's fine to report them so they get worked on, but complaining about them is counterproductive. Rather, it shows you have unrealistic expectations.
When Pluto has received the same amount of work and the same amount of corporate support as Jupyter has, and it still shows the same issues, _then_ you'd be entitled to call the project out for being of low quality and maturity. But not when it's just started.

text: Yes, you have a point.

elements.text: Yes, you have a point.

text:
And just to be crystal-clear, I think it's perfectly fine to report issues with Pluto, whether here or preferably as an issue on Github (that's how the software gets improved). And those issues should be looked into. It's just the tone and the comparison to Jupyter which are unhelpful.
And while it's perfectly natural to be annoyed, it is also natural that pre-1.0 software will not always work as intended, however polished it may already look. So please do not take our reactions to be an attempt at belittling your experience. We just want you to recalibrate your expectations.

And while it's perfectly natural to be annoyed, it is also natural that pre-1.0 software will not always work as intended, however polished it may already look. So please do not take our reactions to be an attempt at belittling your experience. We just want you to recalibrate your expectations.

text:
In fairness to <@U01CQTKB86N>, if this was a personal choice about what to use, it would be different than being required to use an alpha/beta version of a tool for a course. I can certainly understand that frustration.

But that complaint should really be sent to the instructors rather than in a community of people working with / on the tool. I'm really bullish on the future of Pluto (I personally think it's already miles better than jupyter), but not ready to use it in my own course because of how early it is in development.

I'm really bullish on the future of Pluto (I personally think it's already miles better than jupyter), but not ready to use it in my own course because of how early it is in development.

text:
I have another thing with with_terminal() that I don’t know if it’s Pluto or Julia that’s causing slightly odd syntax in my opinion:
This fails on one line:
```with_terminal() do f(1,2,3) end```
this works
```with_terminal() do 
f(1,2,3) 
end```
this works
```with_terminal() do; f(1,2,3) end```

elements.text:
I have another thing with with_terminal() that I don’t know if it’s Pluto or Julia that’s causing slightly odd syntax in my opinion:
This fails on one line:
with_terminal() do f(1,2,3) end
this works

with_terminal() do 
f(1,2,3) 
end
this works
with_terminal() do; f(1,2,3) end

text: Are you running it locally? Can you try only re-freshing your web page next time you see it? The orange banner means the websocket connection to the web process is lost, we don’t communicate kernel shutdowns to the user yet (will in next release)

elements.text: Are you running it locally? Can you try only re-freshing your web page next time you see it? The orange banner means the websocket connection to the web process is lost, we don’t communicate kernel shutdowns to the user yet (will in next release)
